and we get this output signal here and so this is the output
sound signal and what we do is we send it through a segmentation algorithm that
basically breaks up the sound signal into stationary segments or segments
where the sound basically does not change and then within each segment here we
model each of these segments using a wavelet tree
where we're able to basically break it down into its components so we're able to
store it and store each of these wavelet trees saying that this is a wavelet tree for how the texture should sound
based on the speed at which the user was moving during that
original recording and so now we have all this
very complex this very high dimensional data that's stored as a lot smaller
number of data points and then when we're rendering it what we do is we take
velocity we do velocity detection so figure out what is the speed that the person is moving
in the virtual environment select the appropriate wavelet tree
add some add some stochasticity to it because we want to make sure to add some
randomness into whatever noise we're generating because people are very very susceptible
to knowing when things repeat or to knowing when sound clips repeat when vibration repeats so we make sure
to add some stochasticity when we regenerate with the wavelet tree
make sure we do some blending here between
adjacent wavelet trees that we have to blend together so that we don't have
like jumps within the sound signal that we that we are generating

a hundred data points at a time so we are able to update so we're able to update this
